root.geography: most of the Trans-Fly area of the Western District of Papua New Guinea with overlaps into the adjacent parts of Irian Jaya, the Fly Delta area and much of the coastal and estuarine areas and lower courses of rivers to the north of the Fly Delta as far as the eastern bank of Iviri Inlet in the Gulf District, and the eastern islands of the Torres Strait.

child.geography: occupies the Pahoturi River area and the country to the west and north-west of it, as well as, to the north of the Fly River, the corner of country bordered by the left bank of the Fly Delta in the south, the Bamu Delta in the east, and the Lower Aramia River in the north

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 323-344. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.tree-val: Trans-Fly Stock, a sub-tree of the Trans-New Guinea phylum: Wurm 1975

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 323-344. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.tree-val: Trans-Fly Stock, a sub-tree of the Trans-New Guinea phylum: Wurm 1975

child.geography: located in the triangle formed by the Fly and Bamu River Deltas in the south and east, and the lower Aramia River in the north
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 323-344. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.tree-val: Trans-Fly Stock, a sub-tree of the Trans-New Guinea phylum: Wurm 1975
child.pub-comments: Population: 3,000 "Agöb and Idi are almost dialects of one language, sharing about 77% basic vocabulary cognates and being near-identical in structure" (Wurm 1975:330).

child.geography: in the Binaturi and Oriomo Rivers area and most of the country between the Binaturi and Pahoturi Rivers in the Trans-Fly area, and eastern islands of Torres Straits

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 323-344. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.tree-val: Trans-Fly Stock, a sub-tree of the Trans-New Guinea phylum: Wurm 1975
child.pub-comments: Population: 700 "Miriam shares exceptionally low percentages, in the high twenties, with Bine and Gidra, though close to 40% with Gizra. These low percentages figures may be due to the presence of Mabuiag, i.e. Australian, loanwords in Miriam (see 2.16.2.2. [of this book])" (Wurm 1975:329).

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 323-344. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.tree-val: Trans-Fly Stock, a sub-tree of the Trans-New Guinea phylum: Wurm 1975

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.tree-val: Trans-Fly Stock, a sub-tree of the Trans-New Guinea phylum: Wurm 1975
child.pub-comments: Population: 4,450 "The members of the Eastern Trans-Fly family are quite similar in basic features of their structures as well as in quite a few structural details, though there are some difference in the latter, especially between Gizra and Miriam on the one hand, and Bine and Gidra on the other" (Wurm 1975:329).

child.geography: occupies a section of the right bank of the upper region of the Fly Delta, Sumogi Island in the Fly River, and a part of the Mituri River area.

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 323-344. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.tree-val: Trans-Fly Stock, a sub-tree of the Trans-New Guinea phylum: Wurm 1975
child.pub-comments: Population: 220 "…except for Aturu and Lewada-Dewara which, with 78% sharing, could well be regarded as constituting dialects of one language" (Wurm 1975-329).

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. child.pub-comments: Population: 450 "…except for Aturu and Lewada-Dewara which, with 78% sharing, could well be regarded as constituting dialects of one language" (Wurm 1975-329).

child.pub-comments: Population: 1,350 "Within the Tirio family, there is great similarity on the structural level, but the percentages of shared basic vocabulary cognates range largely from the mid-thirties to the mid-forties only…" (Wurm 1975: 329).

child.geography: occupies much of the south-eastern and eastern coasts of the Trans-Fly area, part of the southern (right) and northern (left) banks of the Fly Delta and several islands in it, and the coastal areas and lower courses of the rivers in the Bamu, Gama, Turama, Kikori, Urama, and Era Rivers areas in the Western and Gulf Districts as far east as the eastern bank of Iviri Inlet

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. child.pub-comments: Population: 22,700 "Within the members of Kiwaian family, both lexical and structural relationships are generally close to very close" (Wurm 1975: 329).

child.geography: occupies the Morehead River area and much of the country to the east of it including Strachan Island, as well as the region between the Morehead and Bensbach Rivers, the Bensbach River area itself, and also the Upper Maro River area in Irian Jaya and one village far to the north of the Bensbach area
child.pri-name: Morehead and Upper Maro Rivers Family

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

child.pub-comments: Population: 25 "In the Nambu Sub-Family, Iauga (or Parb) is apparently a dialect of Nambu" (Wurm 1975:330).

child.geography: spoken in the village of Mbur, constitutes the western-most extremity of the family and is separated from it by a stretch of country whose inhabitants speak the Marind language

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.tree-val: Trans-Fly Stock, a sub-tree of the Trans-New Guinea phylum: Wurm 1975
child.pub-comments: Population: 40 "Moraori stands both lexically and structurally rather apart. […] Lexically, it is therefore a member of the Morehead and Upper Maro River's Family only by virtue of a chain-relationship through Kanum and Yey. Structurally, it does also not link closely with the other members of the family, and some of its features show considerable structural and formal similarity to those of the Eastern Trans-Fly family and to a lesser extent, to those of the Tirio and Kiwaiain Families. [...] it may, in the light of what has been said above, well be that a more realistic classification of Moraori would be to assign to it the status of an independent family-level isolate within the Trans-Fly Stock" (Wurm 1975:330-31).

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The Trans-Fly (sub-phylum-level) Stock. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 323-344. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
